title: 110_hr3648
content: The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Act", excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Additionally, the amount excluded from gross income reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The new subsection (h) introduces special rules for Qualified Principal Residence Indebtedness. This includes a basis reduction for the excluded amount from gross income and defines qualified principal residence indebtedness as acquisition indebtedness with specific limits. Additionally, there is an exception for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. The new subsection (h) introduces special rules for Qualified Principal Residence Indebtedness, including an exception for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. Subsection 163(h)(3)(B) applies to the principal residence of the taxpayer, with an ordering rule for discharged loans. The new subsection (h) introduces special rules for Qualified Principal Residence Indebtedness, with an ordering rule for discharged loans. If any loan is discharged, subsection (a)(1)(E) applies only to the amount exceeding the non-qualified principal residence indebtedness. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as in section 121. Coordination amendments are made to section 108(a)(2) and 108(a)(2)(C) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007, with changes to section 108(a)(2) and 108(a)(2)(C) of the Code. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. The amendment applies to amounts paid after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation, including requirements related to gross income, property usage, and expenditures. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act, providing alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section (SEC. 139B) for excluding benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and payments. Deductions and expenses are subject to limitations to prevent double benefits. Definitions for qualified state and local tax benefits are provided. The section defines qualified state and local tax benefits as reductions or rebates provided by a State for services in a volunteer emergency response organization. Qualified payments are defined as payments provided by a State for such services. The term 'qualified payment' refers to payments provided by a State for services as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization, with a maximum limit of $30 per month. A 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' is a volunteer organization that provides firefighting or emergency medical services. The taxpayer performs services for a qualified volunteer emergency response organization, which provides firefighting or emergency medical services in the State or political subdivision. This section does not apply after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Amendment made to section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding student housing eligibility for low-income housing credit. The amendment in section 7 applies the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion to certain post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment in section 7 allows surviving spouses to apply a higher capital gains exclusion of $500,000 for the sale of their principal residence within 2 years of their spouse's death, effective after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is increased from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S Corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries is amended under section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment under section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code limits the disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S Corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries. The new amendment specifies that information disclosed during an inspection or disclosure related to partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns should not include taxpayer identity information of individuals not directly involved in the return or inspection. The effective date for this amendment is the enactment date of the Act, and it applies to returns filed after that date. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. This section adds a penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under the Internal Revenue Code. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 includes a penalty for late filing or incomplete information, with a monthly penalty not exceeding 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. The penalty amount is $85 multiplied by the number of shareholders in the S Corporation. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 can continue for up to 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. The penalty amount is $85 multiplied by the number of shareholders in the S Corporation. The penalty is assessed against the S Corporation, and deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The amendments made by this section apply to S Corporation returns required to be filed after the enactment of this Act. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
